commentBody: Nice snappy Wednesday puzzle!
I’m not a fan of the new stats layout.

"We haven't gotten a cup of tea together in ages!"
"I know, it's been oolong!"

(Sounds like a brew-tiful friendship.)
This was a Monday-level puzzle, for sure.

That was MY CUPPA TEA!!

See you next Thursday!
I put down nueve first instead of siete. I guess math is not my strong suit.   Otherwise it was very easy for a Wed.
Don't love the new phone app stat page layout. What was wrong with the old one where you could see average, weekly, and best times all in one chart?

I had just done the April bonus puzzle (theme=baseball) so when I saw AT BAT and ON BASE and AL WEST I thought this one was going to be another baseball puzzle. But it was tea! And I'm a tea drinker (ASSAM would be my choice from the ones presented here). Jasin says the T shapes of the black squares were coincidental, but they certainly add to the look of the puzzle.

I enjoyed today's Durham-Wordplay lunch, with Wordplayers from Winston-Salem, Greensboro, and Connecticut as well. Great fun catching up on the last year and talking puzzles.

Went down easy like a nice cuppa.

Speaking of “cuppa” - I hadn’t really heard that term used until very recently. I’ve both lived in and frequently visited London over the years but somehow the term never popped up on my “western” radar until the last couple of years when I started noticing it everywhere.

Wondering if cuppa recently spiked in popularity or if it’s just my own selective attention?

As a lifelong tea drinker I enjoyed this tea themed puzzle, and appreciated the cleverness of putting the T in the middle of the teas.  I like OOLONG and ASSAM, but am not crazy about BOBA or MATE.  I used to always solve the puzzle over my morning cup of tea, a tradition I miss since being converted to night time solving.  Maybe I’ll BESTIR myself to go back to morning solving.
Congratulations on your NYT debut! Nice, balanced puzzle. Monday or Tuesday level difficulty, in my opinion, but that’s no shade on the constructor.

Being from Colorado, I enjoyed seeing Elway, though we need a better team. Had MDT since it’s summer first. Unknowingly the team theme also plays well in Colorado as Boulder is the original home of Celestial Seasonings and the Boulder Dushanbe tea house. I am well acquainted with all the teas listed. Strangely Ann Arbor and Michigan are the same number of letters. Was thinking of the university of Michigan Wolverines not the town. Nice premiere puzzle. I disagree with those who thought it was a Monday. Rian’s, bestir, and bobtail made it a nice Thursday

Great debut, Jasin!

Nice theme, crisp clues, no instances of octopi, no rebuseseses...

A pleasant Wednesday solve.
Wow! Super clever, and that was before I noticed the shaded boxes were types of teas :)

Love this! I'm definitely a tea person and caught on before I'd filled in the last theme entry ... though only to the "types of tea" bit, not the T break part. 

Misfills: AVerS before AVOWS because I thought 17A, parsed incorrectly as subcategory and having the first four letters, would be FOOTwear; SOlemn for SOMBER, before I had the downs; and slang before ROLLS.
Nice theme, not too hard. Finished 10 mins faster than my average time!

Fine I guess, especially for a first timer.  But it was awfully easy, and I've never heard of "mate" before. I understand there were constraints, but maybe it would have been best to abort.  Unless "mate" is way more popular than I'm aware of.  The theme can't delight if the references are obscure.

Ah well.  Maybe tomorrow will make up for last Thursday.  :)


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Alas, “Taylor’s of Harrogate Yorkshire” is too long and wouldn’t fit the tea break theme. 

Hmm, scones on the menu tomorrow?
Great Weds puzzle and a nice debut!   I appreciate that even with trivia I didn't know, the crosses eventually helped out so no temptation to look up.  I liked the Tea break theme.
Fun to solve as I was, fittingly, drinking my chamomile cuppa before bed
Fun! I was breezing through it, but I got very bogged down in the upper right corner.

This is such a beautiful puzzle, I'm verklempt and TEAry-eyed.

Okay, so that's stretching it a bit, but I enjoyed the solve and appreciated the theme execution  very much. Well done, Jasin. This was a fine debut and I congratulate you!

I wasn't familiar with BESTIR, but it will definitely go into my lexicon. Especially when I need motivation for something, I will look into the mirror and theatrically command: "BESTIR thyself!" 

Thank you for that new mantra, Jasin, and also for a great misdirect with [Sub category.] Loved it!
I loved this one! Caught the theme early on. A great debut! Thanks.
Re: 41 A https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=DV3BoMy4xxA

As an avid tea drinker, I loved today’s puzzle! I got the first themed entry as I started my first pass through the clues. It was so much fun to see the others appear as I solved knowing the theme. Thank you for a fun bedtime solve.
I'd say this one was a real TEAser.  This or that?  Don't even ask.

Suited me to a tea!

Didn't worry about the theme until the revealer, then realized the shaded squares were teas, and they were all interrupted by Ts. I'd already noticed that the black squares were all Ts as well.

Kind of TEAsed us all through this one, didn't you?

Nice debut, Jasin, and Thanks!

Congratulations on a solid NYT puzzle debut, Mr. Cekinmez!

I don’t often drink tea, but I enjoyed finding the different varieties you put in the puzzle.

Good luck with your remaining studies and I hope we’ll see you back here sometime.
Loved the tea theme! Congrats on your debut.
Super fun, and as a Denver native this puzzle made me happy. Usually I’m terrible at the sports hints unless they’re about the Broncs!

Monday level difficulty.

3/10
PB Wednesday. And I don’t mean peanut butter.
How is tisn't a contradiction? I even checked a dictionary and I'm still not getting it.
Nitpick: Kilograms are units of mass. Newtons are units of weight.

TISNT surely is a negation rather than a contradiction unless you misread (like me) the clue as a contraction …

Nice puzzle. Not Mondayesque as the late night tea drinkers would have one think. A worthy early morning Wednesday.

Above average solve time on Tuesday and my best time for a Wednesday. They were inversed. :-)

Little disappointed in TEA BREAK rather than TEA time as the theme revealer. I have never heard the former.

People solving on Tuesday evening surely should be expecting as Tuesday level of difficulty. 

😀
Great debut, and loved the tea theme! Nicely done!
For a Monday this would be too easy. Are you really that scared of losing Games subscribers?

My last square to fill was where 22D meets 38A. After a while I tried N. I'm not sure why it sounded likely, but it worked. Those, plus 46D which filled in from crosses were the only words in the puzzle that were new to me. Well, the only clue answer words. Two teas don't ring a bell. MATE? BOBA? And I think of ASSAM as a tea-growing region, not as a kind of tea. But I'm only an occasional tea drinker.

Pointless and offensive profanity in service of an unexceptional puzzle. There are good reasons for the long-standing rule against offensive language in puzzles, one being that solvers are forced to write and read this stuff without prior warning. I don’t know why Shortz is permitting this stuff and modifying guidelines that have been around literally since the advent of the the Times crossword,

The newer version of the app on iOS now prompts you to sign into Apple Game Center even if Game  Center is turned off in settings.  While the prompt disappears if you don’t interact with it it’s still annoying.  Who asked for this?

I found this puzzle very easy for a Wednesday - I was not rushing at all, yet I completed it in Monday time - but I enjoyed it. In fact, I rarely like a puzzle as much as I did this one 👍🏾.

I love the look and sound of BESTIR. Usually seeing unusual words (or at least ones I perceive as that) irks me, but this one made me happy, for some weird reason.

I also liked seeing RANT. As you probably suspect, I go off on rants quite often IRL - probably because my Bee esS METER is very sensitive. I do so very passionately and often humorously, putting all my linguistic creativity into twisting Polish into ever new insults. In fact, my wife says my rants were one of the things she fell for when we met almost 20 years ago 🤣. Don't worry though, I keep my rants private, and in relations with other people, also strangers, I'm *much* more likely to be kind rather than brusque 🙂.

I appreciate how two years doing these puzzles meant OBS, RENFAIRE, ENO and ENG were gimmes. Jim - I may often be confused by American culture and language, and I don't care about literally all of it, but I *do* enjoy learning about it most of the time. In fact, the depth of my understanding of the US has improved greatly with these puzzles and this board, and I am grateful for it. Us all over the world learning about one another can only make the world a better place 🫂.

Our eight month old must be going through a growth spurt alongside slowly figuring out how to crawl, because this is already the third time he has woken up to nurse tonight. One of the ways I keep myself awake is doing the crossword then reading the column and comments. But tonight I reached a new level: before he woke me this time I was actually dreaming about reading the comments (and, because of some of this puzzle’s clues, about watching baseball). 

Of course the details have dissolved now that I’m up, but for the brief time before I had to BESTIR myself yet again, I was very much enjoying all the personal anecdotes and wordplay my sleeping brain had invented as well as the unique dream angles from which I was able to observe the pitches during each AT BAT.

Does a puzzle really need five (5) American-specific sport clues? The rest of the world might as well tap out. 

I've made peace with an occasional baseball/American football (not real football if you ask me)/college sports clue, but this felt like way too many.
I’m not a tea drinker even though I live in a town that is well known for its tea.  I did enjoy the clever theme however and look forward to more from Jasin.
Thank you for a very enjoyable puzzle.   Really had fun.   Especially as this was for my 500th solve.   Now I can relax!!

Really nice debut, Jasin.  

I was aware as I solved that TEA names were split, but didn't notice that they were all broken up with a T until I looked back after filling in the revealer.

Regarding the column:

Does anyone actually forgo the top sheet?

It's nice when the theme helps you fill in some letters that you didn't get from the clues, but unlike some, I don't think it makes or breaks the puzzle.  Some people have such a wide range of knowledge that they hardly ever need the theme to complete the puzzle, but they shouldn't assume that others did not find the theme helpful.
Sam found the theme tea-rrifc.  I think if this puzzle was a cat, it'd be the pekoe the litter.

Entered Bennington College 
just as the mayhem of BE Ellis’ book
Less Than Zero 
was causing a stir in book stores
(and stirring up endless on-campus drama).

So the apt crossing of his name
with IDLER -which is precisely what 
I was at Bennington - made me grin.

Toss in a bong  or some rolling papers and it’d be a hat trick!

Thank you Jasin!

Great puzzle! Personally it mostly felt like a Tuesday but the NE quarter was like a Friday to me. It was hard to figure out the two related clues with little to go by, and the difficult BESTIR as a crosser clue. Not complaining though, I am new to the game and have more to learn than to grieve. 

The theme did not help with the dark squares, but the dark squares helped with 52-Across.
I learned that “I wouldn’t” has the same number of letters as DONTEVEN.

Congratulations on your debut, Jasin! 

I was rolling along through the solve and I only stumbled a few times. Somehow, I managed a new PR for Wednesday. Happy hump day!
Understandably, NYT believes that if I solve enough of their puzzles, I will eventually remember all these rappers' names. Well, going on a few years now, and my retention is still zero.
I am missing something here.. the clue “tips” give ENDS?
I had "oby" for some reason and it really screwed me up in that NE corner where two clues were non-existent. I finally came to my senses and finished. whew!

Possible clue for 34A: A semi without trailer, informally.
I usually balk at colloquially or informally tagged clues. Oops, guilty as charged.
Enjoyed figuring out 10D. and 34D.

I was happy to solve a Wednesday 7:25 faster than my average. Nice debut! I’ve been tracking my averages for each day so that I can see how I’m improving. So, I am none too happy about the new stats layout (and have already sent an email to the Games team). I hate having to look at three different screens to compare my daily stats. Why would anyone want them separated? And the graph lines don’t make sense. The line for today is longer than my average (which is higher). Huh? Please email the Games team NYTGames@nytimes.com, if you also don’t like the new stats format. Thanks!

I, who love word quirks, did a mental jaw-drop, when I saw the T, as in “tea”, in the middle of OOLONG, all embedded in a larger word.  My brain simultaneously exclaimed “Huh!” and “Hah!”.  Then, with that larger word, FOOT-LONG, having such an entertaining and original clue – [Sub category] -- well, that’s one of those Crosslandia moments that keeps me coming back for more.

All the theme answers have a nice buzz, and TEA BREAK not only ties them together, but throws in bonus wordplay as well.  Just a sterling theme all around, and having those four T’s made of black squares in the grid is sweet icing.

Give a puzzle bones like that and I’m all in, and nits fly out the window.

The rebel in me likes that EAST is west, and the lover of happy coincidences in me loves that the puzzle finishes with ENDS.

Thus, a splendid outing, and thank you so much for this, Jasin.  Congratulations on your sparkling debut!
I loved this theme! Very clever, right after my tea loving heart!

Typical Wednesday workout for me, and I was almost finished before I finally caught on to the trick. Just a nice 'aha' moment. Enjoyable solve and a clever theme. Appropriate puzzle find today. A Thursday from January 13, 2005 by Robert Zimmerman. Theme answers in that one: TABLEFORT TSCOMPANY TERRIBLETS TBITSWORTH And the reveal (of course): TFORTWO Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/13/2005&g=36&d=A ...

Finding myself with surprisingly little to say. BSMETER has an interesting letter pattern. We had our seemingly obligatory nods to The Simpsons and rap. The theme and fill seem quite solid.

Congratulations on the debut! Time to read some comments ...

My original post seems to have been eaten for the usual inexplicable reasons🤷‍♀️
I repeat:
Any grid that has tea in it gets my vote. *glugs a mug of builders brew* But not BOBA, vile stuff.

With excellent debuts like we’ve had this week, the future of the crossword is secure.

People must commonly make kites using balsa wood, because I've seen it clued that way a few other times, but it seems like it would make for a very fragile kite that would snap with the first hard gust. Probably I just don't understand how it's done.

Mine are made from thin strips of bamboo, with the joints bound with twine, and the twine wrappings subsequently saturated with glue and allowed to harden.

Love a nice cup of tea in the afternoon. Brings back good memories of my lovely mother and the comfort of a small pot of tea with pretty porcelain cups or mugs (with milk and a little sugar), her delightfully silly sense of humor and a little bit time we spent together sharing a "cuppa". Nice crossword. Thank you.

Awesome debut Jasin! Was tea-lighted to see my favorite (non alcoholic) beverage in today's puzzle.

Hope to see more from you soon!

I didn't realize until reading the column that the letter T broke up the tea names. Wow!

This was an impressive debut, and I look forward to seeing more from Jasin!
I still prefer coffee but this puzzle was fantastic fun!
Fantastic debut. It fit to a T. Congratulations, Jasin. Well brewed. 🫖☕️🍵🧋
Wednesday puzzle done to a T...bravo, Jasin, on your debut! I look forward to more...

You had me at OOLONG!
It can be hard to find around here, but it's my favorite, so...I hoard it.  Have never tried MATE or BOBA; ASSAM ....well, India TEA as a whole:  too strong/bitter for enjoyment, IMHO.  YMMV (and any other disclaimers.)  I chose India TEA at a little place near the Salisbury Cathedral (yes, in the UK...in...hmm...1978?)  and it shaped my opinion...and kept me wired for hours!

Wanted THE MANX for the breed of cat.  Have never heard of BOBTAIL (other than "the nag") as a cat breed.  

Anyone else try SERENE and SOLEMN before the actual answers?
Or HEARTHS for radiating warmth?    Synonym City!

Clever idea professionally executed. Congrats on the NYT debut. A smart collection of constructors over at The Princetonian. Perhaps we'll see some of them here someday (if we haven't already). https://crossword.dailyprincetonian.com/
Greatttt............ now i want some tea!

Remember how 200 years ago TISN'T was always clued as [Playground retort]?

FOOTLONG is a genus of subs, not a category. (Subgenus)

The use of teas and T's was fantastic. Great puzzle.

There are no BADASSES only bad owners.

Please have your BSMETERS calibrated and certified before reading my posts.
Feedback submitted 😊. An unfortunate app modification in my view less user-friendly.

I've gone through the existing posts and either I've missed something or none of my fellow Brits have complained about the photo in the Wordplay. Adding a teabag into already milky water! How can you get anything drinkable if you do that?

Jasin's debut was a fine entree to NYT immortality. His self description of what this "rising junior at Princeton" has on his plate leads me to wonder if the phrase refers to his upcoming semester or, instead, to his work ethic. 

Or, as a now-long-deceased undergrad philosopher once put it:
"Early to bed, early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wonder what his roommate looks like."
Good, though I wish there weren't two intersecting sports clues since I always have to guess those!
As a tea drinker, I approve of this puzzle. It also helps that it was clever and well-executed.
Terrific debut, Jasin.  Your hard work is evident. More please.
BAD ASSES and BS METER in the same puzzle? We're through the looking glass on the use of saucy slang, aren't we.
I filled in 57 as campfire, with memories of singing around one with family!  Alas.
The rare reveal that actually reveals.  I had no idea what was going on without it.

EL_AY crossing AL_EST was a complete natick for me. If we can avoid them for proper names, can we please start avoiding them with sports trivia? Actually, one could argue that AL WEST *is* a proper name, as ELWAY very certainly is. So maybe it was a true natick that should have been avoided from the start.
Loved this! Kudos on the debut!
Anytime I see a clue like 49A I quickly look it up and even more quickly forget it. And I don't think that I'M the one who is cheating.

As a native Brit, this puzzle was TEA-ming with fun for me. A rare occasion where I got the revealer on the first pass through the clues.

But I was quickly humbled by the various sports based clues. 

Thanks for the fun debut!

Mostly enjoyable and quite quick, but BS METER does not detect absurdity. It detects dishonesty. If even the Times editors cannot tell the difference between the two, then we're in a bad place literacy-wise!

For those of you who may have followed some of my travel adventures, yesterday, my mother-in-law returned home to the Boston area, so last night was the first night of not having to get up in the night for her in the last almost 4 weeks, and thus today is the first day of our more normal routine... which somehow feels weird after all of this time with Ma. 

All of this to say that it was very difficult to BESTIR meself from mine bed chamber this fair morn. 

Getting to learn a new to me word in BESTIR made it worth it. ☺️

A TEAriffic puzzle. I always wish I could like tea more because I know many teas have a health benefits, unlike my beloved Diet Coke, but I just can't ever get into it for very long. I don't like hot beverages and I do really like cold and fizzy.  

I had a tea loving co-worker friend for many years, who knew I wished I could like tea more. She would leave a large cup of tea for me on my desk every morning. I would drink my Diet Coke, and when that was done, around noonish, when the tea was pretty much room temp, I would drink it. I don't know why she did this so faithfully for me, but it was really sweet!  Her, not the tea. I don't think I've had any since then, over 5 years ago now.

As for my travels, I am very happy to be home, but I also miss being there. Especially my favorite 13-year-old... 13 going on 35, that is. I have known her all of her life but she has definitely entered her teen angst galore and more phase, but I adore that kid!! 😍
I’m having my afternoon pot of tea (Red Bush tea, like Mma Ramotswe) as I peruse the Wordplay comments on this lovely puzzle. I allow myself only one cup of coffee with breakfast these days.

My mediocre writeup for today:
This heatwave just needs to end, or I'm moving to Canada. Holla

I wanted so badly for the solution to “sub category” to be Nautilus, Thresher or Skipjack. It could possibly work in a theme-based Subway, Blimpies or Jersey Mike’s? Nah

I had to chuckle at the timeliness of 8D and 9D, as yesterday our niece, accompanied by her husband, just gave birth to her first child. Is it any coincidence he was born in Ann Arbor. (The baby, not the husband). Thank you Jasin for your clairvoyance.

-> Feeble attempt to harmlessly jab at faultfinders:
I consider today's puzzle impossible to solve, since it contained no less than *five* entries aimed at younger solvers and *two* aimed at the English. How am I expected to know such trivia? Just tisnt my cup of tea. (Hope that wasn't too, too insensitive, I did use “feeble” as a precursor)

I enjoy the word “tectonic” almost as much as I do the word “ether,” although without as much fervor. I'm also a fan of the “be” words; bemoan, behest, bestir, befall, bestride. Not so much besmirch, though, because, well, it's unbeknownst to me.

The “distinctive rear” evoked thoughts of Sam Buttrey’s DontPutYourCat(rhymes with cut)InMyFace. I suppose those songs just write themselves, especially for Steve Martin lookalikes.

Do fish use water-detecting meters?
Do humans still use BSMETERS?
Of course we do! That screen you’re looking at? If it’s on, that’s a definite report of the stuff.

How do I like my coffee? Crisp. 
How do I like my tea? Broken.

As an English person and avid tea drinker I am compelled to comment on 52A. While the acknowledged phrase (and time), familiar to many Americans, is “coffee break,” we English (and other tea drinkers) in Westminster have “tea time” when we enjoy our favourite beverage. This correction would, of course, disrupt today’s theme so I merely put it out there as “drink” for thought.
Besides the types of tea in the breaks did anyone notice the number of black square t’s?  In various directions of course.

Re: 55 down, “Metric wts.”, I do wish you’d stop conflating grams (or kilograms) with weight. Grams (and of course kilograms) measure mass, not weight. A better clue might be something like “Metric meas. of mass”.
ON BASE and AT BAT almost killed me today.
Go Blue! Lovely puzzle

Tuesday time: 12:46
Wednesday time: 6:32

I think Tuesday and Wednesday should've been switched this week!

Nonetheless it was a fun solve, if a bit easy for a Wednesday.

Tea-lightful!
This was a lovely, well planned, well executed puzzle. Thank you Jasin! 

Im another one who didn’t get the rapper or many of the sports clues, but the crossings were do-able, esp with help from our wonderful Sam Corbin - oh how I enjoy your columns, Sam!

I agree that they must have mixed up Tuesday and Wednesday this week, cuz I set a PR and still haven’t finished the tuesday…

I love the lil uzi vert clue cuz it gives me a leg up on the general NYT crowd. Yall should listen to more mumble rap. He’s been big for >7 years now, check out XO Tour Lif3 or I Just Wanna Rock.

Fun puzzle! This puts me in mind of another puzzle, by our hometown girl, Kelly Richardson...check it out and you will see why: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2024/07/16 Very well-received, and coincidentally, also a debut!
@J me either! I don’t like it. And what’s up with Tiles?

@Mike

Sencha asked, I've been brown-bagging my lunch lately.

Cafeteria prices are too steep.  Tired of getting soaked.

I'll put a note in my loose-leaf so I won't forget.

@Mike

Matcha do about nothing, my darjeeling...


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@Mike

How can such a murky cup suit me to a tea?  It's a major grey area.

@Mike

You're quite good at this, ain'tchai?

@Mike
I don't know how you avoid being mugged.

@dutchiris

I made an EARLier mistake about the grey area!  It was bound to happen sooner or latte.

@Dave K.

Almost exactly my Wednesday average time.  I wouldn't be so sure.
@Jim Same here.
@Eric agreed

@Eric Agreed. I wouldn't mind it broken up by day -- with the old setup it was hard to see the ATB differences in Monday times because the bars were to scale for Sundays -- but comparing ATB for a day is more useful than comparing averages for the whole week.

@CarolinaJessamine

oops, sorry! Yes, Beautiful Downtown Efland, too!
@Striker.  Good ear. Ngram viewer shows a tenfold increase since the mid-1990s

@Bob
Thanks for pointing me to Ngram Viewer! Just played around with it for 10 minutes. I hadn’t heard of it and it’s really interesting. Gotta love words.
@Striker Cuppa is extremely common in Australia too, for many decades. Although, it's more of a generic term for any hot beverage in a cup/mug. Cuppa tea? Coffee? Hot Chocolate?
Now that you mention it, of course. In fact, maybe originated there? Has a definite Australian feel to it like “brekky” or “footy”.
@Striker Yes. A cuppa is usually enjoyed with some bikkies (biscuits)...the cookie variety, not bread.

@Paul
I’m on my way.
Ngram is new to me, too.  "Literally" shows a big surge in the last 20 years.  No surprise, there.

@Jim,

Usage of that word has literally exploded.

@Striker

Tangentially, I just finally used NGram Viewer to look up one of my pet peeves - how everyone uses "back in the day" and pretends it's perfectly normal.

NGram shows what I felt to be true - the darn phrase basically didn't exist until 1999 or 2000, upon which it shot up like a rocket.  Trendy twits.  I don't mind neologisms, but don't gaslight people and pretend you're not engaging in them.

Both cuppa and back in the day also have a sneaky air about them in that they sound old timey while being brand new.  The insincerity bugs me...

(I was fooled by cuppa though - I assumed it was an English nana thing.)

@B

"in my day" had been around for a while, and I think that got overtaken by the more recent "in my day".

@Jim

i meant the more recent "back in the day".  Back in the day my brain worked a lot better.

@Marshall Walthew

OOLONG and ASSAM are varieties of tea; BOBA is a product made with tea, while MATE is a tea-like drink which isn’t actually tea. At least I think this is the case; too early in the morning to do actual research.

@Steve L

Mate is considered an herbal tea.

@Jim

Many would say that herbal teas aren’t actually tea, that tea is only made from the leaves of camellia sinensis.

@Steve L

In Poland it is illegal to sell anything else than proper tea under the name "herbata" (tea). Herbal infusions and the like are usually called "herbatka" ("little tea", literally).

@Steve L

And many who order tea at a restaurant (in America, at least) would expect that an herbal tea might be one of the choices.

@Jim

My transplanted elderly mom never got used to the fact that when she ordered "tea", in North Carolina, expecting a hot drink in a cup and saucer, a cold, achingly sweet drink would appear.

@Megan

Some of my happy days as a kid in Colorado were visiting the Denver area.

I lived in the heat and rusty air of Pueblo, but I got to go to Denver once a year on my birthday.

When we did, we stayed at a motel my aunt and uncle managed on Colfax Avenue in Aurora.  It may still be there.  It's called the Riviera.
@Francis the hotel is still there.

@Megan

Amazing.  As I recall, that part of town has not done well over the decades.  I suspect it's a place I wouldn't stay these days.

But at the time, swimming in the motel pool with my cousin...it was wonderful.

It seems that the motel survived the entire family of my aunt, uncle, and two cousins.

Hi, @Francis!
Late in the day yesterday, I left a reply in a thread whose biome had become decidedly snarky. And, like burning fossil fuels in a green-house world, my comment only served to increase the snark levels. I just wanted to make sure that you knew that the snark wasn't directed at you, personally.

@Isabeau
I had the same misfills. I also had pedi/serene instead of mani/sedate. Both made sense to me given the clues. Fun puzzle!
@B Yerba mate, very trendy
@B Mate is HUGE in South America. Also, it’s the main ingredient in Celestial Seasoning’s Morning Thunder, if you’ve ever had that.

@Mary

Okay thank you.  I stand clarified and corrected.  So it was a me issue.

"Yerba" rings a bell but I missed out on the mate part.


____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
@B Also it's pronounced mah-tay, not  mayt like (check)mate, so if you hear "Yerba maté" spoken it's not obvious that it's spelled like that.

Yerba MATE used to be a fad in Poland several years ago. There were bags upon bags of the stuff under multiple South American brands at the shops, and all the paraphernalia for brewing it. On the internet on various fora (computer and tech, automotive - nothing to do with tea) people discussed their favorite brands and how they managed the brewing. I never got into any of it, and even though I understand you may not have heard of it, I don't think one can call mate obscure, objectively.

In common use they are both. I’m a doctor, we record people’s weight all the time in kg not newton.

@Ιασων Indeed! And in the middle of the night I went down that rabbit hole of units of force and the semantics buried therein. It always boils down to semantics when we pick nits, no?

I guess all measures of weights are measures of force, specifically of gravity, even our beloved outdated American pounds and dry ounces. While mass is independent of any force, gravity or otherwise. In any case I will sleep better tonight I hope, with the mass of my mattress exerting a force upwards upon me that is equal to that of my weight, so as to stop me from tumbling further down any dark passages, rabbit or otherwise.
@SP in pedantry corner for the fun of it only: you measure a BMI not a BWI 😀
@Monika Eckhart I've heard 'tea break' more frequently than 'tea time'. I explored a bit and seems 'break' is used more often as a break from work while 'time' is more of a casual catch-all

@CB
Tch! A tea break was a regular contractual feature across the pond, just as lunch breaks are here (unless the US labour laws have been repealed.) There have certainly been strikes over attempts to reduce or eliminate them.

@SBK
Now legally termed rest breaks. If you work more than 6 hours a day you are entitled to an uninterrupted rest break of 20 minutes. 
For a very long time for many it was a 'tea break', often in a works/staff canteen, or a sit-down with a flask of tea, or a trolley came round offices with a big tea pot.
Work practices have changed so this is now not such a feature.

ANN ARBOR was a gimme with just a few crosses - not because I knew the sport team, but because last year in Stralsund, Germany, in a gothic church turned into an art gallery, we visited an exhibition of photographs by Leni Sinclair, and Ann Arbor featured prominently there.

Combined with LOO, the clue "Camper's recreation" made me laugh. In the British car show Top Gear one of the hosts, Jeremy Clarkson, a curmudgeonly hater of the outdoors at the time, went on a camping trip. He understood none of the appeal. At a campsite he asked an elderly couple in a caravan what it was one could actually do there. The lovely lady was momentarily confused and finally said: "Go to the loo." (I used to enjoy camping for decades btw, with a tent. I only grew out of it in my 40s).

I liked the theme. It was sort of random, but the revealer was nice, and the theme was well implemented in its individual entries. It actually made me smile, which is rare, and especially unexpected this week. Thank you, Jasin Cekinmez 🙂.

I wanted to thank the community again for the support you showed me. Talking with people and knowing they have my back, seeing the good in their hearts, feeling heard and understood - it all helps me deal with my grief at the loss of my best friend, Jorge the Lab ❤️

@Francis

Matura was actually quite pleasant and easy for me. I aced it. That was because back then the only obligatory subject for everybody was Polish (Lit, to you), and I was great at it. Or rather, I was great at the more important half of it - writing essays. The thing was, the Polish test started with an essay. If you aced it, you did not have to take the other half of the test - an oral examination on 3 millenia of literature (but mostly on the one millenium of Polish lit). I would have hated taking that, because it involved a frackton of rote learning, but I didn't have to.

It was also obligatory to take a test in one modern foreign language. I picked English and aced it, too (duh).

And finally, the third obligatory test was in a subject of your choice. You could pick, among others, math, physics, chemistry, biology, history, geography, or Latin. However, I did not have to take this test at all. I had taken part in a nation-wide history competition (called the Polish History Olympiad), and I had aced it, thanks to support from my historian father. Not only did that allow me to skip 1/3 of matura, it also gave me access to almost all courses at any Polish university. I picked (probably quite badly) the Law and Administration course at the Facility of Law and Administration of Warsaw University (Law School, to you). The rest is history, happily free of any math, but with an amazing Labrador.
Faculty, google, faculty. Facility... SRSLY.

@Nancy J.
Indeed! The duvet is enveloped in sheeting — sort of like a pillowcase, but buttoned or zipped shut. I think it’s the most wonderful way of sleeping (typical for Germany and Scandinavian countries). The feet are free and not clamped down between sheet and mattress.

@Nancy J.

Raised by a Swede, and we never had a top sheet. 
Hotel beds felt so complicated.

The inserts are washable, but the covers 
just went in the laundry every week with 
the pillowcases.

And, no sharing! 
Everybody gets their own!

My Swedish cousins couldn’t believe
Americans have to share a comforter.

“So, then do they have to share a long pillow?”

Heh, we hauled ours from home to Europe. I have family in Norway and my cousins came to visit a little while back. My little nieces were thrilled by this novel and strange way of “sleeping American.” 

@Hobby Gardener — your feet can be free under the top sheet. I never tuck mine under the mattress.

@Nancy J.

I'll second @Hobby Gardener

Over in Poland at home we place our duvets in larger versions of pillow cases, buttoned or zipped shut. We don't use top sheets.

Hotels all over Europe do use top sheets, though, and I always find them awkward. The first thing I do when I check in is pull the edges of the top sheet from beneath the mattress, to regain the freedom of movement under the duvet I'm used to.

I suppose hotels do it because staff can much more quickly arrange the top sheet set-up rather than awkwardly pull cases onto hundreds of duvets daily, and the top sheet is also roughly half the weight of a duvet case, which must make a difference in washing them.

@Nancy J.

Hmm. TIL. Seems like an encased duvet only gives you one option—on or off. Layers of top sheet, thin blanket, then comforter gives flexibility to adjust throughout the night. And, yes, hospital corners are just for looks and must be undone for sleeping.

@Nancy J.

I didn’t notice that either—nice extra touch!

@Andrzej

Our summer duvets are thin cotton, and the inserts are much
less dense and lighter.

Winter covers are fleece or flannel and heavy and cozy.

It somehow seems more sterile, though washing a flat sheet (as long as one’s feet haven’t touched the comforter) is equally germ-free..?

@Nancy J.

Thank you for starting the discussion about top sheet or not! The comments have been enlightening - I did not know "direct to duvet" was a thing apart from my daughter always throwing her top sheet off the bed LOL.

@Bruce
My very first kite as a kid somewhere in the early 60's was a mail-ordered Jolly Green Giant kite. We saved up enough labels from cans of peas, plus a couple of dollars, and the rest is memories.
The sail was made of a thick plastic sheet, and the spars were flexible plastic tubes. We taped the tubes with the enclosed materials.
I've owned several as a kid, I do remember buying the balsa kit from the local hardware store.
Great memories!
